overviewQuestion.questionText: What is episodic angioedema with eosinophilia?
overviewQuestion.answerText: Episodic angioedema with eosinophilia is a disorder characterized by episodes of swelling under the skin (angioedema) and an elevated number of the white blood cells known as eosinophils (eosinophilia). During these episodes, symptoms of hives (urticaria), fever, swelling, weight gain and eosinophilia may occur. Symptoms usually appear every 3-4 weeks and resolve on their own within several days. Other cells may be elevated during the episodes, such as neutrophils and lymphocytes.[11620][11621] Although the syndrome is often considered a subtype of the idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndromes, it does not typically have organ involvement or lead to other health concerns.[11620][11622] The cause of this condition is unknown. Treatment may not be needed, but can involve the use of steroids.[11621]

basicQuestions.questionText: What are the signs and symptoms of episodic angioedema associated with eosinophilia?
basicQuestions.answerText:
People with episodic angioedema associated with eosinophilia (EAE) experience recurring episodes of the following symptoms:[11621][11622][14526]
  • Swelling under the skin (angioedema)
  • Hives (urticaria)
  • Fever
  • Swelling
  • Weight gain
  • Reduced production of urine
Laboratory findings during these episodes may include:[11621][14526]
  • An elevated number of the white blood cells known as eosinophils (eosinophilia)
  • Elevated levels of certain antibodies, including IgG and IgM
The episodes usually occur every 3-4 weeks and resolve on their own within several days. There may be an increase in urine production once symptoms resolve.[11622]

references.authors: Khoury P, Herold J, Alpaugh A, Dinerman E, Holland-Thomas N, Stoddard J et al

basicQuestions.questionText: What causes episodic angioedema with eosinophilia?
basicQuestions.answerText: The cause of episodic angioedema with eosinophilia (EAE) is not well understood. Experts suspect that certain proteins  in the immune system called interleukins may play a role. Specifically, interleukin 5 (IL-5) levels are elevated during episodes. Studies have lead to the belief that these proteins play a role in the inflammatory process involved in EAE.[14526]

references.authors: Liu F, Hu W, Liu H, Zhang M, Sang H

basicQuestions.questionText: How might episodic angioedema with eosinophilia be treated?
basicQuestions.answerText: Treatment may not be needed for episodic angioedema with eosinophilia (EAE), since symptoms usually resolve on their own. When treatment is initiated, steroids are usually the first choice. Certain medications used to treat cancer, including Imatinib (Gleevac) have also been successfully used in treating EAE.[14526]

references.authors: Liu F, Hu W, Liu H, Zhang M, Sang H

basicQuestions.questionText: What is the long-term outlook for episodic angioedema with eosinophilia?
basicQuestions.answerText: Generally, episodic angioedema with eosinophilia (EAE) is considered to be a benign condition with a self limiting course. Typically, other organs are not involved and over time, episodes may resolve on their own.[12728] In some instances, people with EAE can develop symptoms in other organs, such as cardiac disease.[14528] Symptoms may also progress to other types of non episodic hypereosinophilic syndrome.[11622]

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
